attributes.alt: Cover for Bird Builds a Nest by Martin Jenkins. Cover shows a bird building a nest in a tree.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with an activity, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What did Bird need to do to build her nest?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing opportunities for measurement.
Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.
Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Subitize the number of items in a group up to five.
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Have children use the 5-frame to get from numbers zero to five total sticks.
Was anything being built in the book? Describe it.
Pretend to gather objects for a nest like Bird.
How many worms will you put out for Bird to eat?
Write a story or real information about a bird.
Can you make a bird’s nest?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of
Use blocks and other objects to build a bird’s nest. Why did you use those objects to build the bird’s nest?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to identify problems and their solutions and focus on operations.
Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.
Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Subitize the number of items in a group up to five.
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Explain that 5-frames can be used to understand and solve math problems.
Guide children to use the 5-frame to add numbers of materials from the book.
Does anyone in your book have a  problem? What is it?
Can you move like a bird?
Can you show three on a 5-frame? What about one more?
Have you ever had a problem? What did you do to solve it?
Can you make or draw a bird in a nest?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word
Did you make a plan for what you are building? Have you had any problems while you are working? How will you try to solve them?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to discuss measurement, engage children a game, and introduce vocabulary
Read interactively for a closer understanding of the story and weight.
Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.
Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Subitize the number of items in a group up to five.
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Try to use new words and grammar.
State multiple ideas in a single sentence.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Guide children to use the 5-frame to subitize numbers between one and five.
Challenge children to display numbers in a 5-frame.
Is there anything in your book that is heavy? Is there anything light?
Can you pretend to carry something really heavy?
Which items feel heavy? Which items feel light?
Can you write about a problem you’ve had? How did you solve it?
What materials would you use to make something heavy?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of
How could you make what you are building heavier? How could you make it lighter?

attributes.alt:
Big Chart of Big Ideas for The Three Little Rabbits. Chart shows rabbits making 3 different houses. A wolf tries to blow all 3 down but finally fails.
Ryan Rabbit made a house of straw. Ricardo Rabbit made a house of sticks. Rebecca Rabbit made a house of bricks. The wolf blew the straw house and the house of sticks down. The wolf couldn’t blow the brick house down.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:  The Three Little Rabbits

attributes.alt: Cover for Bird Builds a Nest by Martin Jenkins. Cover shows a bird building a nest in a tree.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to get children excited to read about building on the Big Chart of Big Ideas and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to measurement by discussing whether different building materials are heavy or light.
Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.
Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Subitize the number of items in a group up to five.
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Use counters on a 5-frame to represent bags of materials.
Have children use 5-frames to determine how many bags are needed to have five bags in all.

Pretend to be building a house. What materials are you using?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to connect the book to scientific thinking, engage children with a song, and review vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
Why did Bird build a nest?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on measurement.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to 5 objects.
Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Ask and answer questions about a text.
Try to use new words and grammar; State multiple ideas in a single sentence.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
What materials would you use to build a house? What would your house be like?
Save children’s responses to display next week.
Did you like this book? Would you tell a friend to read it? Why?

Write a story about an animal building a home.
Can you draw a cozy home? Show me the parts that make it cozy.
. What sound do you hear at the beginning of these words? What letters make that sound?
